posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17459077
Beaufort is shown on the left.
Lalique is a weird one, but probably niche-like. They own Gres and Alain Delon (both based), they make the juice for Brioni (very mid), they make the really popular and hyped Bentley stuff as well as the drug-store tier Jaguar stuff. They still have some old school and daring offerings, but their portfolio includes fragrances to match the current tastes. Overall, they are drifting towards the right side but are still on the left as of now. Now be aware that this is my personal opinion and not the opinion of the maker of that image (and that that image is also not part of the OP of this general).
Chanel is another "linewalker", in my opinion. Diverse offerings, but it's a private company which hasn't sold out yet.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Guerlain is the best fragrance house for men for a variety of reasons, namely their illustrious history and their association with Napoleon Bonaparte. Established in 1828, Guerlain was founded by Pierre-François Pascal Guerlain, and quickly became a favorite of the French royalty and aristocracy. In 1853, the house received its first accolade for its Eau de Cologne Impériale, presented to Emperor Napoleon III. This same fragrance was also presented to the Emperor's wife, Empress Eugénie, and was a favorite of the royal court.

In addition to its royal heritage, Guerlain's fragrances possess an unparalleled distinction and sophistication. Their fragrances are renowned for their ability to inspire and captivate with their exquisite aromas and classic designs. With their signature scents of jasmine, lavender, and sandalwood, Guerlain's fragrances have the power to evoke timeless emotions and memories.

Given Guerlain's impressive history and the exquisite quality of their fragrances, it would be foolish not to wear them. They are the epitome of luxury and elegance, and are sure to make any man stand out from the crowd.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17459227
Funnily enough, Sauvage does slightly fit the bill. While it is a spicy showergel fragrance, it isn't overly sweet (in my opinion). Starts off with a pepper blast and goes into the aforementioned showergel territory. Of course, the main gripe most people have with it is how overused it is.
1 Million is sweet, and while many people liken it to bubblegum, it's not bubblegum-sweet. The cinnamon-leather drydown is really nice. Fahrenheit is based and seems to be making a comeback. From what I've heard, the latest reformulations are on point in terms of scent as well. It is an older fragrance and might smell like an older fragrance to some, but it does fit the bill. Kouros was rather fresh to me, but too much urinal cake. I haven't smelled Gentlemen, but the accords on fragrantica might be slightly telling. "Fruity" and "sweet" are high on the list, but I think that the original recommendation was for the 1974 version of Gentlemen. That juice does no longer exist.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Waiting for my Bianchi's Sticky Lips-release to arrive in the mail, hard to find any discussion about it online. I really hope the rose is somewhat on the resinuous and red side if there are animalic notes (as most Bianchis) and powderiness to it. Also have Iris Malikhan coming as soon as Essenza fucking ships my bottle which I have soon been waiting for 2 months.

My next buy is probably one of the following:
>Parfum d'Empire: Le Cri
just a fantastic, almost transcendental rose. when I think of a sophisticated fragrance, this is it.
>Papillon Perfumes: Tobacco Rose
after going through most of my 5 ml along the past year I was sure I would never, ever be associated to this fragrance again. it was too green, too fresh. but I feel like my taste has changed and the later drydown of Tobacco Rose has so nice, sweet elements to it. it's almost like there was honey lieing in the very base that comes through after the bitter and vegetal start. Papillon is such a great house.
>Hiram Green: Arbole, Arbole
sampling Arbole didn't really make me too excited, but now after working with Arcadia I really love the concept and the quality of Hiram's fragrances. I would love to buy Slowdive but I feel like it's a little too unwearable, and Arbole Arbole is second in the line.
>Beaufort London: Acrasia
This is a little premature since I'm just waiting for my sample, but based on the notes this might be a bottle that I'm going for next.
>Rania J: Musc Muschous
Another fragrance where the notes seem to tick everything that I'm currently going for. Waiting for sample.
>something by Les Indemodables
I really enjoyed Antoine Lie's work with this house. just not sure which of the fragrances would be a bottle, so I might still go for a second round of samples.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>17460731
Guerlain Vetiver is a classic men's fragrance that was first released in 1961. It is a woody, earthy fragrance with tobacco notes and a hint of citrus. The top notes consist of lemon, bergamot, and pepper. The middle notes consist of vetiver, tobacco, and oakmoss, and the base notes consist of tonka bean, cedarwood, and patchouli.

Over the years, Guerlain Vetiver has become a classic men's fragrance, and is still popular today. The tobacco notes are the star of the show in this fragrance, creating a smoky, masculine scent. The citrus and pepper top notes give it a sharp, fresh start, and the vetiver, oakmoss, and patchouli in the middle and base notes provide a woody, earthy undertone.

Overall, Guerlain Vetiver is a classic, timeless men's fragrance that has stood the test of time. Its tobacco notes give it a smoky, masculine scent that is perfect for any occasion.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It is out of the box bros. Not sure if anyone will recognise it but a gorgeous vintage styled fruity chypre. I feel as though in a way Sacred Scarab by Zoologist took a certain feeling or accord of Kolonya and turned it into a resinous chypre. This in turn feels like Rasei took Sacred Scarab and put his accords prominently in view again in the form of a chypre (this is obviously not literally possible since both releases were worked on probably similar times, it is just a way to express the idea of this perfume). Sadly I don't think anything can really capture what Kolonya was, even his own work, for how reminiscent it is, never really captures that certain mixture he made in his magnum opus. I think why I compare it so heavily is because of some base or accord he came up with, I've heard several people talk of Andy Tauer and other perfumers and how they have their own "tauerium" and so forth to mark their work with a familiar and signature style, so too does Rasei do this, sometimes moreso than others.

Review aside, box posting was all just in good fun, bring some life and fun to this thread while I unbox my new frag, I have a tight collection and aside from my boring work safe frags I don't bother splurging on anything I don't find resonance with. Sadly this is a limited release but I do hope his main line-up reincorporates some of these ideas. I see some votes in fragrantica linking this to All the Queens Men, how I do not understand, they are nothing alike. Also like I alluded, it is not like Kolonya but regardless it is great in its own right. Try if you can.

Ah nah it really doesn't have any relation to Kolonya, think I made it sound somewhat confusing because I somehow forgot to mention the name of this frag. This is his new limited release, Under Which Rivers Flow, it's his first foray into chypre (though he doesn't label it as such anymore, he used to on his insta but I think it veered too far off what he would think a chypre is or something?). I mention Kolonya because some people compare it and because it has his signature fruity style that is slightly reminiscent of it (people compare Impressions de Giverny and Fatih Sultan Mehmed to kolonya for similar reasons). Ultimately Kolonya is fresher and manages to find complexity and real depth in the realm of a light and warm weather fragrance, which to me is deeply impressive. I love Kolonya and am sad I will one day run out, this is not a substitute, nor any of the fragrances people compare Kolonya to.

Imagine a fragrance (an imaginary one, really). It's worn by a hot dog salesman in New York. posts.name: Anonymous

>>17461172
Most of my stuff has been bought in person & as I’ve said it’s hard to find NA stuff in YG let alone made specifically for men, I assume that all mine is pretty old & from when gold was cheaper. As far as artists there’s hundreds of very collectible, talented artists just gotta do some research. Normally older stuff especially “old Indian pawn” is most desirable, all that means is it was made by Indians for Indians & not to sell to whites or tourists. Stuff from the 50s-80s is also very desirable as it has turquoise from mines that are no longer active. I’m from the east coast but my grandparents moved out west & spent their retirement buying southwestern/western/NA art (Remington bronzes, Pueblo pottery, paintings, ect) so I learned a lot about it from him. Look for shops in wealthy western towns in Utah, Colorado, Montana, Wyoming, arizona, & so forth. There’s unending research to be done on the topic tho, I’ll link u cuff I really like that’s two tone & some other reputable dealers, you can search for gold products on there sites I’m sure but good stuff gold or silver won’t be cheap.

Never bought from any of these but have looked around, all have some nice stuff.
www.abbykentflythefineart.com

www.fineindianart.com

www.sedonaindianjewelry.com

www.shopgarlands.com

Below is some good resources.
www.horsekeeping.com/native-american-jewelry-artifacts.htm

Finally that cuff I was speaking about. they have a smaller one also but I think it’s a bit mass produced & over priced, my big cuff was less than that, it does look nice tho. tomtaylorbuckles.com/collections/bracelets-cuffs/products/carico-lake-turquoise-cuff

>Finishing not significantly improved over $500 level

For me, I'll stick with my quartz Tissot until I can justify the cost of a watch that actually does something unique and interesting with its mechanical movement.

I'm aging well so far, but I sure as hell am trying to do my best to not leave it up to chance. I'm 26.

I do A313 retinol, sunscreen (if I actually go out), cleanser and moisturizer.

I eat once per day to stay lean and to have long periods of fasting. It's surprisingly easy to get used to this, and I love overeating, so anyone can do it. Lost about 15kgs now that I can confirm with scales in a few months. I'm poor so my diet is not perfect.

I don't smoke or drink. I used to drink beer more often, but I cut it out almost entirely. I like wine and live in a wine country, so I might drink a glass rarely.

I will start doing cardio, but I don't want to overdo it. I've heard HIIT is better for the body than traditional long distance running. NGL I was never good at this so I'd like to get in conditioning where I can run 30km at least once in my life.

I will start supplementing collagen, 25g per day when I can afford to buy it in bulk per kilo.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
As someone who will soon finally get his own place, all of these images are nice to look at, but most of it is completely impossible to recreate or even pull inspiration from. They're mostly dependent on very high ceilings, structural/architectural one-of-a-kinds, centuries old wood flooring/mediterranean tiles, few thousand dollar designer pieces and huge indoor plants. Recreating the feeling of those rooms in a normal apartment or even a house is futile. Some might see those pics and think "Oh I'd like to live like that", but forget that to even dream of achieving the same vibe, you'd first need a location that allows it; most people don't. Just buying a few old antique chairs and placing them in a new apartment with low ceilings, laminate flooring and white PVC windows will look like ass.
I'd rather like to see more normal, well-thought-out room concepts, even if the wow effect might not be present as much.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
depends on what country and era you're going for. american skinheads arent the same as british skinheads, and rac/oi music scene focused skins arent the same as ska skins.
im assuming youre not interested in that spirit of 69 kumbaya crap. "racist" skinhead style is about looking militant (particularly 90s, 00s), so i recommend you milsurp, especially for the pants. bleach splatter jeans are said to have originated as homage to camo. german skinheads could often be seen wearing commie era deadstock (personally i own a tanker jacket). american "skinheads" (known for their sloppiness) can even be seen in cargo pants, as opposed to the traditional jeans or sta-prest pants. and the poles you notoriously would see wearing adidas shoes (but this is not out of line with the "traditional" look, as skinheads were associated with adidas sambas).
the traditional skinhead style is about being proudly working class, but being put together. your clothes should be clean, ironed, and you should carry yourself with dignity. polo shirts, button up shirts, as opposed to tracksuits.
modern "racists" prefer the so called "casual" style, of wearing ellesse and bucket hats. personally i hate it. i dress smartly in the 70s way, or 90s if i feel like being edgier.
>rugged black belt
get suspenders instead. nothing screams skinhead like a pair of suspenders.
dont bother with new doc martens, the company went downhill and only makes shoes for lesbians nowadays. if youre fine with the vintage look, brogues and similar are good too.
any blue jeans will do. make sure to roll up the cuffs. slim fit is better than baggy.
bomber jackets are a skinhead staple, but anything oversized and open at the front will do. a chunky cardigan is just as good. you want a top heavy silhouette.
sweaters/vests with the collar poking out look smart too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17461878
Only solution for preserving the flags would be to remove them and sow them back on after dying. I removed mine but it wouldn't be particularly difficult to reattach them. Personally I'd leave them off but it's up to you.

3 things to keep in mind if you're going for the look in this photo: it's night time, metro stations have cold lighting, and the dye hasn't faded. Your jacket will look like this, but then it will fade. Personally I made 2 attempts, once with cheap Rit dye, which faded quickly, and then a second attempt using two 0.75oz bottles of Jet Black Procion MX and soda ash for activation, stirred in a 5 gallon bucket and left overnight. After the second attempt it looks the same as your pic and the color has held, for now anyway. I wouldn't recommend any other dyes but ymmv. Procion makes 8oz tubs, I'd recommend buying one of those so you have extra on hand. Don't get too attached to how it looks right after dying. Put it through the wash twice (preferably a washer you don't own) or dye will rub off on your skin and cloths. It's an 80/20 cotton synthetic blend so there's only so much you can do. It'll fade in the wash and it'll fade in the sun. The nice thing is that if you don't like the result or it fades too much you can always re-dye it.

Also here's some interesting Rick trivia on the subject of dying army surplus:
>"WHEN I FIRST STARTED MAKING CLOTHES, ALL THE PUNK KIDS USED TO BUY ARMY SURPLUS—THEY DYED IT BLACK. THOSE WERE MY FIRST COLLECTIONS, MADE OUT OF USED DUFFEL BAGS AND ARMY BLANKETS FROM HOLLYWOOD BOULEVARD. THERE’S A MELANCHOLY ROMANCE TO THOSE BLANKETS, BECAUSE THEY’VE BEEN USED IN THE MILITARY.” THE INFLUENCE, HE REVEALS, SEEPED PERMANENTLY INTO THE DEFAULT OWENS COLOR PALETTE. “YOU SEE, THE DYE YOU GET AT THE GROCERY STORE IS CHEAP, AND IT DOESN’T MAKE A GREAT BLACK. SO ARMY-GREEN CLOTHES IN BLACK WOULD FADE INTO THIS WONDERFUL GREEN-MURKY BLACK THAT I ALWAYS USE IN EVERY COLLECTION. I CALL IT EITHER DUST OR DARK SHADOW.”

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: Am I wearing the dreaded "dad shorts?"
posts.com:
For context I am 32, so is my wife, and our son is 3. Here is a photo of the three of us together in a family photo showing off the "dad shorts" in question. I put that in quotes because I myself am not quite sure.
I remember growing up as a child and teenager my dad used to wear some quite outdated short shorts that were literally just as short as my mom's shorts, and to me it always looked silly as hell. So in rebellion to not be anywhere close to his style I wore the baggiest, longest cargo, basketball, and boardshorts you could find. Those motherfuckers must've been around 12 to 15 inch inseam or some shit. They hit mid-calf are were almost the same length as my pants, just with a small piece of the calves showing.
Eventually though...I realized this looked kind of juvenile and just moved on to wearing pants all the time. The pants themselves were also the right fit. Not too baggy, but not too tight either. It looked a bit more mature.
Relatively recently though my wife told my I looked really nice in boxer-briefs, that I had really nice legs and thighs, and that I should definitely wear shorts out in public more. I told her I literally didn't own any shorts anymore for years, and she gave a "say what" type of reaction, and literally took me shopping for shorts the next day.
Since I hadn't worn shorts for years I just kind of took her advice on everything. She said shorts should not be super baggy or tight, but either relaxed or fitted. She also said that shorts should literally be "short" as the name says, and definitely hit a good few inches above the top of the knee or even mid-thigh is fine; but that they shouldn't go shorter beyond that or else you start to breach "70s short shorts territory." This all made perfect sense to me. The length was both comfortable and looked good. So we bought several pairs of shorts in the 5-7 inch inseam range for me.
However, once I posted the photo shown, a lot of my friends made fun of me for wearing "dad shorts."

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17456900
First of all, you have curly hair. Secondly, only using shampoo will keep stripping all of the hydrating oils, which is what is making it so frizzy.

Use shampoo and then conditioner, only wash your hair every second night, and use a conditioning mask for 10-30min once a week. Don't rush your hair once it's dry - just run your fingers through while the conditioner is in it to separate tangles. You'll get some nice, smooth waves and curls.
You can use a leave-in oil product too if you want to go the extra mile. I out maybe a tablespoon of oil in my hair while it's soaking wet out of the shower, then leave to air dry (but it's much longer than yours, you'll figure out the perfect amount.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17455402
>>17455864
Yeah, it's a bad faith argument. When you say "milsurp" and ask if it can mix with TIP, you're obviously not asking if trench coats and khaki pants and desert boots are TIP, because they obviously are. You're asking if you can wear flecktarn and spetsnaz boots with a TIP fit and not look ridiculous, and the answer is generally "no." If you're going for the TIP aesthetic but like milsurp, that's fine, but save it for an appropriate situation like going hunting.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17455373
I'd say I take a middle ground on this issue. Clothes that would be worn in combat 1970s-onward would clash, because combat gear from then on has been so drastically different from normal clothing. Earlier than that could possibly work, depending on the item. There are a lot of WWII items that can work with TIP clothes while still having more of an obviously military appearance than older heritage items like trench coats. Pic rel is a menswear blogger I like wearing a vintage Marine Corps service jacket with a TIP resort outfit.

Hard to give specific advice without knowing your body type, height, whatever. Most of your basic stuff sounds fine though. Graphic tees can be a bit childish or stupid depending on the design so you could replace those with plain. I like oversized t-shirts or jackets but tighter stuff works too if you think it flatters your body.

If you want to go fancier than that, you could check out the "academia" aesthetics. Stuff like turtlenecks, knit sweaters, chinos, shorts, button down shirts can all look normal but feminine depending on the cut and sizing. Most women irl don't casually dress that differently from men in actual items, it's just the fit that differs a lot.

Don't wear skirts, though. Skirts, thigh high socks, and weird purses are the most obvious stupid choices trannies make in public.

oh almost the same as me then. Are you wearing women's clothes most of the time then? I have trouble finding men's clothes that are tight on me.

I think the oversized top and skinny pants or shorts combo works pretty well. I think that tighter shirts can seem more "twink" than "girly" if you have a normal male body with wider shoulders than hips, but either is fine if you like it. I don't recommend wider pants because they hide your butt and they make short ppls legs look shorter imo. You want to ideally make your legs look longer and your torso look less long.

For clothes since you are short and skinny there are a lot of options that could look feminine without seeming tranny. Basically anything outside of dresses or skirts might be good. Also avoid anything that emphasizes your shoulders ofc. Plain t shirts look classier than graphic tees and turtlenecks can be very nice. Also try wearing more colorful stuff. I didn't change the kind of clothes I wore but stopped wearing mostly black/gray and it helped a lot.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17457501
Off the rack shoes can’t fit everyone.
People heel to ball ratio, heel size, ball width, etc differ.
Each makers employ different lasts. Someone can fit size 7 in one brand fine, but won’t in another brand’s 7.
If that last RMW uses don’t fit you well, see if they have anything else or move on the another brand.

For future purchase, learn your feet features, things like high or low instep, heel size, ball width, arch, heel to ball measurement, relay those infos to the brand, ask them to describe how their last fit to you.

Ultimately, this takes trials and errors, you just have to get the shoes on your feet to know for sure. It helps to work with retailers who can offer return/ exchange.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17457342
What is happening here might be that the last heel to ball ratio is farther than your feet’s, so your feet widest part is actively sliding up that point, making slippage happens.

Either buy one of those glue on heel piece in smaller size or get a cobbler to stitch a piece of leather to the heel to bulk it up. The heel tabs you use is too thick, thats why it feels cramped.

/btg/

What do I need to care for my boots?
>Old cotton t shirt (one for cleaning, another for applying conditioners)
>Horsehair brush ($10-15)
>Wooden shoe trees ($10-15)
>Light conditioner like Lexol/Bck4/renovateur
>Heavy conditioner (if you live in terrible snow/rain areas) Sno seal/Obernauf LP
>Don't forget that boots need time to dry properly, rotate them and don't wear them daily for too long

How do I deal with x stain?
>mud: allow it to dry then brush off
>salt: water and cloth as soon as possible
>saturated wet: allow the boot to dry for a full day, stuff with newspaper
>scuffs and scratches: buff vigorously with horsehair brush

>Should I buy turdsdays/soloshits/doc shitans?
No they are filled with synthetic materials aimed at instant comfort but will not hold up to actual use.
>b-b-but muh ecelebs on youtube said they're good
no. you will waste your time and money and still have uncomfortable footwear at the end of the day. spend the extra $100 and get something real.

Manufacturer Red Flags
>Luxury
>Sustainable
>Vegan
>Unknown leather source

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17461072
I use these spenco inserts:
https://www.amazon.com/Spenco-Comfort-Lightweight-Cushioning-Orthotic/dp/B000S6JTMG
I've seen these everywhere, from Amazon to Wal Mart to Target. What I like about them is that they're flat enough to where it does not interrupt the contour of the inside but thick enough where it can fill out an extra quarter to half size, no problem. They're also soft enough to cut with scissors if they don't fit in the toe box.
You can find leather inserts pretty cheaply (<50 bucks) if you visit any red wing store and ask for them. They won't mind that you're using them in Chippewa boots one bit.

>>17457021
>What type of pants replace jeans?
Chinos, pleated slacks, trousers, etc. Jeans are really a pretty solid choice, but I totally understand the frustrations with them. Take the time to understand cuts and what you like. Do you like a slimmer fit or a more relaxed one? Do you like your pants to have a taper? Just as a rule of thumb, don't get skinny jeans. They can work, but they won't for this look.

>Can you wear loafers with a black t shirt or do you need to wear a collar?
You can, and it will look good. You can wear anything with anything, and 90% of the time if it looks intentional it'll work.

>can oxfords be worn casually
Yes. People might get pissy and say they can't be, but if you can wear oxfords with a casual fit and it looks good, then it looks good.

>do you need a belt
No, not if you have well fitting pants. They never hurt though, it's a nice touch for your shoes to match your belt.

>what are some essentials for this
For picrel, none of the clothes are unusual, they just fit well. Also he's pretty jacked. Anyways, you could probably make any plain solid-color shirt work (preferably not garish colors), then those pants have a taper to them and are a pretty slim looking cut. I might suggest something with a little higher of a waist though, but that's just my personal taste. As for shoes, it sounds like you're on the right track - honestly as long as you aren't wearing sneakers, running shoes, or work boots, you're probably looking good. Glasses, watch, and jewelery are done to taste.

This >>17434391 is the advice you need. Just keep in mind what type of fit you're looking for. If you're considering getting one of their slim or slim tapered fits, be honest about whether this could be a little too tight. I've owned a pair of their slim tapered jeans and wore them for a few months only to find out that I absolutely hate the fit and prefer their straight tapered fit infinitely more since it gives me workable crotch mobility and doesn't have the feminine appearance of having the thighs too tight and the calve region being loose. If you order a pair only to find out you should have gone just one size up in waist, Iron Heart's customer service is top notch. If you're american, you could order a pair from Self Edge, Iron Shop Provisions, or Division Road and not have to deal with the longer shipping times from shipping overseas to Iron Heart's HQ in the UK.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Assuming you’re her big brother, you should talk to her anon.
As for the appearance of preexisting scars I recommend a silicone gel as it’s what I used to fade the more prominent/red ones and it’s available over the counter/online
Tretinoin cream (or any retinoid really) also works but you would have to get a prescription but most family doctors would prescribe it to her for scarring. It’s typically used to treat acne scarring but it’s available in higher concentrations for scars not located on the face.
Bio-oil works although it’s less effective for larger, raised scarring. It’s contains vitamin A, C, E that help help with skin health and repair. Also available OTC

Source, I used to live on a farm and self harmed a bit when I was really angsty as a teen. When I moved out I worked in a glass manufacturing plant as a glazier for a couple of years while going to school and got myself good like 3 times

>>17452675
Fasting + strength training is ideal for weight loss. Muscle gain raises your baseline energy consumption so you can keep fat off even after you stop fasting, and no exercise causes muscle atrophy (which means no hungry muscles to consume food right away). Pushups and squats with no weights are enough for the average person. Just start with 10 of each every weekday and work up your way from there.
